From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


This page deals with the deletion discussion and speedy deletion processes. For articles deleted via the "Proposed Deletion" ("PROD") process, or simple image undeletions, please post a request at Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion
"WP:DELREV" redirects here. For Revision Delete, see WP:REVDEL.

Formal review processes

Deletion review
Move review
Administrative action review

For RfCs, community discussions, and to review closes of other reviews:Administrators' noticeboard

For bot-related matters:Bots noticeboard



Evaluating consensus before closing:Discussions for discussion

Deletion review (DRV) is for reviewing speedy deletions and outcomes of deletion discussions.  This includes appeals to delete pages kept after a prior discussion.
If you are considering a request for a deletion review, please read the "Purpose" section below to make sure that is what you wish to do. Then, follow the instructions below.


Purpose

ShortcutWP:DRVPURPOSEWP:DRVPURPOSE
Deletion review may be used:

if someone believes the closer of a deletion discussion interpreted the consensus incorrectly;
if a speedy deletion was done outside of the criteria or is otherwise disputed;
if significant new information has come to light since a deletion that would justify recreating the deleted page;
if a page has been wrongly deleted with no way to tell what exactly was deleted; or
if there were substantial procedural errors in the deletion discussion or speedy deletion.
Deletion review should not be used:

because of a disagreement with the deletion discussion's outcome that does not involve the closer's judgment (a page may be renominated after a reasonable timeframe);
(This point formerly required first consulting the deleting admin if possible. As per this discussion an editor is not required to consult the closer  of a deletion discussion (or the deleting admin for a speedy deletion) before starting a deletion review. However doing so is good practice, and can often save time and effort for all concerned. Notifying the closer is required.)
to point out other pages that have or have not been deleted (as each page is different and stands or falls on its own merits);
to challenge an article's deletion via the proposed deletion process, or to have the history of a deleted page restored behind a new, improved version of the page, called a history-only undeletion (please go to Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion for these);
to repeat arguments already made in the deletion discussion;
to argue technicalities (such as a deletion discussion being closed ten minutes early);
to request that previously deleted content be used on other pages (please go to Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion for these requests);
to attack other editors, cast aspersions, or make accusations of bias (such requests may be speedily closed);
for uncontroversial undeletions, such as undeleting a very old article where substantial new sources have subsequently arisen. Use Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion instead. (If any editor objects to the undeletion, then it is considered controversial and this forum may be used.)
to ask for permission to write a new version of a page which was deleted, unless it has been protected against creation. In general you don't need anyone's permission to recreate a deleted page, and if your new version does not qualify for deletion then it will not be deleted.
Copyright violating, libelous, or otherwise prohibited content will not be restored.


Instructions
ShortcutWP:DELREVDWP:DELREVD
Before listing a review request, please:

Consider attempting to discuss the matter with the closer as this could resolve the matter more quickly. There could have been a mistake, miscommunication, or misunderstanding, and a full review may not be needed. Such discussion also gives the closer the opportunity to clarify the reasoning behind a decision.
Check that it is not on the list of perennial requests. Repeated requests every time some new, tiny snippet appears on the web have a tendency to be counter-productive. It is almost always best to play the waiting game unless you can decisively overcome the issues identified at deletion.
Steps to list a new deletion review
If your request is completely non-controversial (e.g., restoring an article deleted with a PROD, restoring an image deleted for lack of adequate licensing information, asking that the history be emailed to you, etc), please use Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion instead.


 


1.


Click here and paste the template skeleton at the top of the discussions (but not at the top of the page). Then fill in page with the name of the page, xfd_page with the name of the deletion discussion page (leave blank for speedy deletions), and reason with the reason why the discussion result should be changed. For media files, article is the name of the article where the file was used, and it shouldn't be used for any other page. For example:

{{subst:drv2
|page=File:Foo.png
|xfd_page=Wikipedia:Files for deletion/2009 February 19#Foo.png
|article=Foo
|reason=
}} ~~~~



2.


Inform the editor who closed the deletion discussion by adding the following on their user talk page:

{{subst:DRV notice|PAGE_NAME}} ~~~~


3.


For nominations to overturn and delete a page previously kept, attach <noinclude>{{Delrev|date=2025 August 27}}</noinclude> to the top of the page under review to inform current editors about the discussion.



4.


Leave notice of the deletion review outside of and above the original deletion discussion:

If the deletion discussion's subpage name is the same as the deletion review's section header, use <noinclude>{{Delrevxfd|date=2025 August 27}}</noinclude>
If the deletion discussion's subpage name is different from the deletion review's section header, then use <noinclude>{{Delrevxfd|date=2025 August 27|page=SECTION HEADER AT THE DELETION REVIEW LOG}}</noinclude>


 

Commenting in a deletion review
Any editor may express their opinion about an article or file being considered for deletion review.  In the deletion review discussion, please type one of the following opinions preceded by an asterisk (*) and surrounded by three apostrophes (''') on either side.  If you have additional thoughts to share, you may type this after the opinion.  Place four tildes (~~~~) at the end of your entry, which should be placed below the entries of any previous editors:

Endorse the original closing decision; or
Relist on the relevant deletion forum (usually Articles for deletion); or
List, if the page was speedy deleted outside of the established criteria and you believe it needs a full discussion at the appropriate forum to decide if it should be deleted; or
Overturn the original decision and optionally an (action) per the Guide to deletion. For a keep decision, the default action associated with overturning is delete and vice versa. If an editor desires some action other than the default, they should make this clear; or
Allow recreation of the page if new information is presented and deemed sufficient to permit recreation.
Examples of opinions for an article that had been deleted:

*'''Endorse''' The original closing decision looks like it was sound, no reason shown here to overturn it. ~~~~
*'''Relist''' A new discussion at AfD should bring a more thorough discussion, given the new information shown here. ~~~~
*'''Allow recreation''' The new information provided looks like it justifies recreation of the article from scratch if there is anyone willing to do the work. ~~~~
*'''List''' Article was speedied without discussion, criteria given did not match the problem, full discussion at AfD looks warranted.  ~~~~
*'''Overturn and merge''' The article is a content fork, should have been merged into existing article on this topic rather than deleted. ~~~~
*'''Overturn and userfy''' Needs more development in userspace before being published again, but the subject meets our notability criteria. ~~~~
*'''Overturn''' Original deletion decision was not consistent with current policies. ~~~~
Remember that deletion review is not an opportunity to (re-)express your opinion on the content in question. It is an opportunity to correct errors in process (in the absence of significant new information), and thus the action specified should be the editor's feeling of the correct interpretation of the debate. Deletion review is facilitated by succinct discussions of policies and guidelines; long or repeated arguments are not generally helpful. Rather, editors should set out the key policies and guidelines supporting their preferred outcome.
The presentation of new information about the content should be prefaced by Relist, rather than Overturn and (action). This information can then be more fully evaluated in its proper deletion discussion forum. Allow recreation is an alternative in such cases.

Temporary undeletion
Admins participating in deletion reviews are routinely requested to restore deleted pages under review and replace the content with the {{TempUndelete}} template, leaving the history for review by everyone. However, copyright violations and violations of the policy on biographies of living persons should not be restored.

Closing reviews
A nominated page should remain on deletion review for at least seven days, unless the nomination was a proposed deletion. After seven days, an administrator will determine whether a consensus exists. If that consensus is to undelete, the admin should follow the instructions at Wikipedia:Deletion review/Administrator instructions. If the consensus was to relist, the page should be relisted at the appropriate forum. If the consensus was that the deletion was endorsed, the discussion should be closed with the consensus documented. 
If the administrator closes the deletion review as no consensus, the outcome should generally be the same as if the decision was endorsed. However:

If the decision under appeal was a speedy deletion, the page(s) in question should be restored, as it indicates the deletion was not uncontroversial. The closer, or any editor, may then proceed to nominate the page at the appropriate deletion discussion forum, if they so choose.
If the decision under appeal was an XfD close, the closer may, at their discretion, relist the page(s) at the relevant XfD.
Ideally all closes should be made by an administrator to ensure that what is effectively the final appeal is applied consistently and fairly but in cases where the outcome is patently obvious or where a discussion has not been closed in good time it is permissible for a non-admin (ideally a DRV regular) to close discussions. Non-consensus closes should be avoided by non-admins unless they are absolutely unavoidable and the closer is sufficiently experienced at DRV to make that call. (Hint: if you are not sure that you have enough DRV experience then you don't.)

Speedy closes
Objections to a proposed deletion can be processed immediately as though they were a request at Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion
Where the closer of a deletion discussion realizes their close was wrong, and nobody has endorsed, the closer may speedily close as overturn.  They should fully reverse their close, restoring any deleted pages if appropriate.
Where the nominator of a DRV wishes to withdraw their nomination, and nobody else has recommended any outcome other than endorse, the nominator may speedily close as "endorse" (or ask someone else to do so on their behalf).
Certain discussions may be closed without result if there is no prospect of success (e.g. disruptive or sockpuppet nominations, if the nominator is repeatedly nominating the same page, or the page is listed at WP:DEEPER).  These will usually be marked as "administrative close".
Active discussions
27 August 2025
26 August 2025
Semi-metro
Semi-metro (talk|edit|history|logs|links|watch) (XfD|restore)
Hello everyone, I'm aware that the majority of votes indicated to merge. However, in my opinion the AfD-discussion focused on the term, rather than on the subject/topic of the article. The subject/topic (being "partial grade separated light rail") meets WP:GNG and I think this warrants a separate article.— Preceding unsigned comment added by KatVanHuis (talk • contribs) 13:02, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

Endorse The original closing decision was sound. Discussion of the term was relevant. If the subject of the page is simply “partial grade-separated light rail” it can be covered within the light rail article. There is no compelling reason presented here to overturn the original closing decision. -- RickyCourtney (talk) 14:10, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Procedural close as a blatant abuse of process. The appellant bludgeoned the AfD with 18 comments, all saying basically the same thing, and is now here for yet another free bite at the apple. Merge was the clear consensus in this widely participated AfD, and even the appellant admits so. The only basis for this appeal can be summed up in the words of Captain Tenneal: "Well, you're all wrong!". I don't think we should waste another hour on this, let alone seven days. Owen× ☎ 14:15, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse:
This appears to be a case where one editor in an AFD mistook length of argument with strength of argument and so thinks that they should have prevailed in the AFD by filibustering.
This appears to be a case where the appellant is saying that the closer was wrong because the closer did not supervote.
The instruction to drop the stick is overused, so my reference to it is preterition.  Robert McClenon (talk) 17:17, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Self endorse, KatVanHuis checked in with me before opening this, and I saw no other way to close the discussion so I was happy for them to bring it here for more POVs. Star Mississippi 23:46, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse. Editors are authorized to decide not to retain an article about a topic that meets GNG (a scenario discussed at length in Wikipedia:Notability, the same guideline that includes WP:GNG). There was a consensus to merge.—Alalch E. 00:41, 27 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
25 August 2025
Lilyfield light rail station
Lilyfield light rail station (talk|edit|history|logs|links|watch) (XfD|restore)
There are a number of issues with the closure, which also apply in the case of the simultaneously-deleted Juniors Kingsford light rail station page. I will preface all of this by apologising for unwittingly violating the WP:CANVASSING policy. The editors whom I pinged ought not to be disregarded for this unbeknownst policy breach of mine. Those whom I pinged and who responded were right to be alerted to the topic, having contributed extensively to this and related subjects, and should have their arguments taken seriously, because those arguments are sensible. My actions here constitute a significant flaw in the discussions and the ability of the closing editor to make a sound judgement, but they are not the only error in the proceedings.
My arguments will refer to both articles since the issues are essentially the same. Hence, if possible, I would like for this application to be considered to concern both.
Consensus has been misinterpreted, in that it does not exist. OwenX rightly corrected me in noting that AfD discussions are not a mere headcount. But, the editors who advocated for maintaining these articles – which for nearly two decades have cycled between creation and erasure – made valid points in regard to both policy and widely-established practice in terms of covering transportation infrastructure. The opposing argument based on the GNG treated it as gospel rather than guidance, and particularly fails to account for the realities of covering public transportation infrastructure – even when notable. Per the policy, a topic can meet the criteria but not be notable, or vice-versa. One may refer to the articles for stations of London's Tramlink, the G:Link, the Canberra Metro and Manchester Metrolink to grasp this, as well as New South Wales articles such as that for Macdonaldtown railway station (which has referencing to a similar quality as the latter stage light rail articles) or nearby Ashfield (inferior). I accept if the latter portion of this paragraph is beside the point for the purposes of this review, and advances an argument which belongs only in an AfD discussion. I do not know, so I have chosen to make this point.
In any case, it is worth noting that the discussion for Lilyfield was tied, whilst the Juniors Kingsford discussion was 5–4 in favour of redirecting (not counting the initiator). It is unclear what may have been the result with more time, or with wider engagement.
As stated, discussions on this matter have been unending. Previous discussions have usually found in favour of retaining light rail station articles in Sydney, the most recent occurring this year. Such discussions took place in March 2006, December 2006 (twice concurrently), and from January to March this year. These discussions indicated general support for retaining or re-establishing station articles. Articles for all then-operational light rail stations were available until 2013, when they were summarily erased as part of a broader reorganisation. As I understand it, articles are not supposed to be endlessly re-litigated.
The discussions, in the unusual way they were held, have led to the bizarre situation of two articles being redirected whilst others exactly of their kind remain. These cover Wentworth Park light rail station, Circular Quay light rail station, Randwick light rail station and the Central light rail platforms. These are, likewise, healthy articles. Another editor suggested that the practice of these two discussions being held concurrently violated WP:MASSAFD and WP:RUSHDELETE. The length of the discussion periods may also have been insufficient, even though one was extended, given the history of these articles being created and erased – a history which will not end here.
The articles were significantly expanded, in the case of Lilyfield by myself and in the case of Juniors Kingsford by myself and one other editor, after the recent discussions began. This directly implicates the arguments supporting erasure made in regard to length, notability, the availability of sources (though there are broader limitations concerning public transportation infrastructure) and duplication. It is arguable that, if the station articles could aptly be merged into the line articles beforehand, then this is no longer ideal. Further, the coverage of other stations has the potential be expanded in a similar way, which would lead to significant bloat should everything continue to be centralised in one document. This centralisation discourages the improvement of coverage.
In 2006, arguments in favour of retaining station articles were partially predicated on the notion that, over time, the articles might grow. Indeed, this has borne true, with the length and quality substantially improving over time (see the Lilyfield article in 2012 compared to recently; Juniors Kingsford station did not yet exist). These articles will later exist in further improved form, regardless of the recent erasure. They will be reinstated as reliable coverage continues to grow, just as they have been previously. (The sourcing on the Lilyfield article was actually better than on the line article, as I recently rectified errors which still exist in the line article.)
Due to the failures in the discussions wrought by myself and the initiator, consensus is not determinable. There may have been flaws in the arguments advanced by myself and others for retaining the articles, but these are balanced by the oversights of those who advanced erasure. The articles should be reinstated, pending yet another discussion if that is deemed necessary, continuing the endless back-and-forth. Will Thorpe (talk) 08:54, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

No action because of WP:TLDR. In view of the limited resource that is our volunteer time, DRV requests should not be, as in this case, longer than the article at issue.  Sandstein  11:28, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
@Sandstein I acknowledge that it is long, but that seems a little unfair. There are multiple issues at play here which I have sought to outline. The fates of these articles (plural!) do matter, even if they are relatively small. I, too, sacrificed some time of my own to outline these issues when I am busy with a number of professional and scholarly commitments. I did this for the benefit of those such as you.
I have seen that on many days, there are no deletion review requests at all. I can italicise or bold the key points, if that helps. Will Thorpe (talk) 11:36, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
If one divides the length of my response by the number of times that this discussion has occurred, and given the fact that it concerns two articles in the same position, then perhaps the length is a little more understandable. Cheers, Will Thorpe (talk) 11:51, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse.  Good close.  Lots of weak !votes were appropriately downweighted.  There was a consensus to redirect with the third !vote, and nothing added after changed it.  Some source analysis could have trumped, but there was none.  On my analysis, the first three references do not meet the WP:GNG.  I think there is no commentary on the station, the article was just a collection of rolling facts. Articles need secondary source content.  —SmokeyJoe (talk) 12:50, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Review the article reference lists and you will find that the majority of information is attributed to secondary sources.
@SmokeyJoe, in which article are you referring to the first three sources? If it is Lilyfield, then NSWrail is a resource used on just about every rail-related article for New South Wales. So is Transport for NSW, a government agency.
Per Wikipedia:WikiProject Australian Transport/Sources, Transport for NSW is held to be reliable; NSWrail has not been adjudicated on. Now look at the reference list for Summer Hill railway station, which is referenced about as well as most railway stations in New South Wales; dare I say in most of the world. Ashfield railway station, Sydney is larger, yet is more reliant on these sources. The truth, which complicates matters, is that articles concerning public transport have always struggled with WP:GNG, even when they are clearly notable. This is why it is important to remember that GNG is a guideline. Will Thorpe (talk) 13:08, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Interestingly, these larger stations also have substantially smaller article bodies. I do not know what the difference is that could make them notable and these not. Would you have an answer? Will Thorpe (talk) 13:12, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Notable means that others have written about it.  “Writing about” does not include compilations of facts. I’m looking for subjective adjectives. I am talking about the difference between primary source material and secondary source material, using definitions from the field of historiography.
The three sources I looked at are:
1. https://transportnsw.info/routes/details/sydney-light-rail-network/l1/780l1
2. https://glebesociety.org.au/socialhistory/rail-transport-in-glebe/
3. http://www.nswrail.net/lines/show.php?name=NSW:wardell_road_central
SmokeyJoe (talk) 13:55, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
@SmokeyJoe, in that case, I have addressed two of the sources you refer to directly – and they are probably used on every public railway station article in New South Wales, and for others related. All up, that will account for close to five hundred articles – stations and other railway infrastructure. Likely more. For many of those articles, the proportionate reliance on those sources is greater than in the articles herein discussed, yet there is still no question of notability.
If you please, look at the reference list on Ashfield railway station, and from there look at as many other railway stations within NSW as you can. What makes the reliance on these sources disqualifying here despite them being essential everywhere else? Ashfield fails the test, and so does Summer Hill, Thornleigh, Penrose, Martins Creek, and most others that do not have a heritage listing. Also look at the size and scope of the article bodies – often smaller than these articles with less information uniquely relevant to the specific station.
Once again, it becomes clear that the GNG is a useful guide, but it is not wholly determinative or infallible – and it stresses this fact.
What makes these articles different? Will Thorpe (talk) 15:51, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Be careful with WP:OSE arguments. For instance, if Ashfield railway station came up at AfD, if I looked only at the sources in the article, I would !vote to delete it. SportingFlyer T·C 17:12, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Transport for NSW is not an independent source and is thus ineligible for notability discussion. NSWrail is clearly an amateur SPS and so is also ineligible. JoelleJay (talk) 20:56, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse Look, this is way too long of a petition, and the bolding makes it really difficult to read. But it is still a petition. First, it is that there should have been no consensus; second, that this is a continuous area of conflict; third, that the articles were expanded, fourth that other stations articles remain... et cetera. The problem for those wishing to keep the article is that this does appear to have been correctly decided, even ignoring the WP:CANVASSING, and that's because the keep !voters did not accurately identify sources which mean the stations are eligible for standalone articles, and at least two of the delete/redirect !voters noted that sources were not readily available, which weakens the !keep arguments greatly. I also looked at the article under the redirect, and I don't see any clear error having been made here by the !voters. My advice: if there are sources on this specific station, find them, make sure they pass WP:GNG, and then restore the articles. You could do this at AfC, or if you find (multiple) sources and want them reviewed just ping me on my talk page and I will let you know if they are good enough. SportingFlyer T·C 17:11, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse the close of Redirect as an Alternative to Deletion that was the best close by the closer in this situation:
The appellant cites ongoing discussion as a reason not to delete, but is doing much of the discussion, so that this is a filibuster.
The appellant says that the articles should be retained, and they are being retained in the article history.
ArbCom recently reaffirmed in the capitalization case that editor time is our most important resource, and the appellant is wasting editor time.  Robert McClenon (talk) 17:59, 25 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
On your last point, the deletion of multiple articles, in the context of a dispute that has lasted nineteen years, is quite frankly worth at least five minutes of time. @Robert McClenon, forgive my slight disdain for that condescending statement of yours. You might forget that I, too, and a volunteer, with numerous obligations beyond editing this encyclopaedia. Yes, what I wrote was long, but it was done in good faith and intended for your benefit. Will Thorpe (talk) 14:07, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse None of the keep voters provided evidence that the station met WP:GNG or WP:NTRAINSTATION which are the relevant guidelines; the canvassing did not help matters either. The closer was correct in downranking the weaker keeps. Jumpytoo Talk 02:37, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse. You can't both oppose mass AFDs and oppose different articles being listed separately with different outcomes. Stifle (talk) 10:51, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse. The closer appropriately read the consensus in the AfD. Dclemens1971 (talk) 18:39, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse Owen's close as the only possible accurate reading of consensus. Every single keep !vote was devoid of a P&G basis; ignoring them entirely would be perfectly valid. The blatantly LOCALCON, canvassed discussion on the Sydney light rail TP also smacks of WALLEDGARDEN and this topic area should probably get more eyes. JoelleJay (talk) 21:06, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse. The keep advocacy was really weak in their arguments. About the bizarre situation of two articles being redirected whilst others exactly of their kind remain: That's normal. Some Pokemon have separate articles and some don't. Predictably, what appears to have happened is that these other articles of the same kind that "bizarrely" still exist as standalone articles have been nominated for deletion following this DRV nomination... —Alalch E. 22:58, 26 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

Pete Tyler – Vacated and relisted by original closer. (non-admin closure) Left guide (talk) 03:33, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]


The following is an archived debate of the deletion review of the page above. Please do not modify it.



Pete Tyler (talk|edit|history|logs|links|watch) (XfD|restore)
Incorrect interpretation of consensus. There were no formal votes for a merge, and only one commenter mentioned it as a possibility. There was no dialogue about a merge between editors.4meter4 (talk) 02:59, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

(closer)You could have engaged on my talk page - I don't think my history of closes shows that I'm inflexible when it comes to engagement. That said, it's here now.  Briefly, while there was no consensus for delete, there was a strong rebuttal that the sources presented were about the episode rather than the character, which had remained unanswered for eight days. To my interpretation, merge seemed a stronger representation of the evolution of the discussion outcome (as against an aggregate summary of its elements). Regards, --Goldsztajn (talk) 03:12, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
@Goldsztajn I'll remember for next time (if there is one) to reach out first. I think a relist with a question about merging to guide future discussion would have been a better choice. We actually do need to discuss an WP:ATD and gather a consensus through talking before going that route in a formal close. Best.4meter4 (talk) 03:16, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
(edit conflict) @4meter4 I was in the process of replying that I had misread the timeline - it's been eight days since the relist, not since the last round of comments. While there's no time restrictions on closing AfDs after the first relist, I have no problem with a relist here. Regards, Goldsztajn (talk) 03:19, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
I've gone ahead and reversed my close and relisted. Regards, Goldsztajn (talk) 03:30, 24 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]


The above is an archive of the deletion review of the page listed in the heading. Please do not modify it.

The following discussion has been closed. Please do not modify it.



I am requesting review of the closure of the AfD for Adeeb Ahamed.
The AfD was closed as “delete,” but this does not reflect a genuine consensus. Several substantive “keep” arguments were made, supported by reliable sources, yet the outcome appears to have been shaped primarily by the repeated interventions of a single experienced editor arguing for delete. Per WP:CONSENSUS, consensus is not a vote count, but nor is it determined by repetition or seniority. Where multiple good-faith, policy-based arguments remain in conflict, the appropriate result is *no consensus*, not deletion.
Sources and notability  
During the discussion, and in follow-up searches, multiple significant independent sources were identified spanning more than 15 years. Examples include:  
- The National (2020) — coverage of Ahamed’s role in hospitality expansion.  
- The National (2023) — reporting on financial services expansion into Saudi Arabia and India.  
- Gulf Business (2020) — feature interview on the Covid-19 crisis, remittances, and industry outlook.  
- Gulf Business (2021) — industry analysis on remittances and digital payments.  
- Business World (2018) — analysis of post-GST expansion strategy.  
- Indian Express (2018) — reporting on major cultural patronage and civic engagement.  
Together with earlier references already cited in the AfD, these sources span a period of well over a decade. That breadth makes it clear this is not a case of routine or trivial mentions, but of sustained, independent editorial interest in the subject’s business trajectory, policy positions, and civic role.  
This directly rebuts the claim that coverage is “routine” or “promotional.” Features in outlets such as Gulf Business, The National, Business World, and Indian Express are independent, reputable, and provide the depth of analysis required under WP:GNG.  
Procedural concerns  
AfD exists to test whether notability can be established, not to delete subjects who clearly generate significant coverage but whose articles happen to need improvement. Here, sources establishing WP:GNG were present or easily located, and the discussion reflects ongoing dispute about interpretation, not lack of sourcing. The closure therefore risks confusing “lack of unanimity” with “consensus for delete.”  
Request  
I ask that the close be overturned to *no consensus*. This would reflect the actual balance of arguments, acknowledge the presence of significant sources, and avoid setting an unreasonably high bar for WP:GNG based on one editor’s repeated assertions. Fintechtri (talk) 21:42, 16 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

To preface this, I had initially nominated the article for deletion due to its total lack of sources outside of the timespan of a single week, making it fail WP:SUSTAINED, and, thus, be an open and shut notability failure, as Wikipedia is not news. While the sources were enough to pass WP:GNG, that is not the sole metric of whether an article is encyclopedic enough. However, due to it being a very popular slang word, it was quickly bombarded with many, many keep !votes, many of which were pure votes, as is par for the course on popular pages. Numerous others argued that it passed GNG, which I agreed with, but wasn't the actual crux of my argument at all. While sources were added to the article in the course of the discussion, they didn't address the SUSTAINED issue. One was from 2022, but not actually about the word at all. Of the people who DID acknowledge the argument made in the discussion, a full six people supported temporary draftification, though one person later changed their !vote.
I expected it to be relisted due to the lack of substance of the keep arguments, which would undoubtedly be seen by a seasoned admin, who would allow more time for the minority view of draftification. However, this closure came out of left field by a non-admin and stated that it was a SNOW keep decision, completely ignoring the draftification !votes, of which there were still several. It did not even mention them at all, or why SUSTAINED was suddenly invalid somehow, making me feel like there was no well-reasoned closure here, and at best it was very rushed. While I attempted to bring up the issue with the closer, they stood heavily behind their decision. At the very least, if this is upheld, I would like the rationale modified to add some sort of policy reason why besides just "SNOW keep" and "Article got expanded since the original deletion nom", even if the expansion does not address the problem.  ᴢxᴄᴠʙɴᴍ (ᴛ) 21:10, 13 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]

Relist or reclose (involved) - reiterating my comment at the closer's talk page, I think that a keep outcome is a reasonable reading of the discussion but the close rationale is insufficient and I don't think SNOW applies, and I question how much article improvement during the AfD really impacted the course of discussion (the other statement in the close). signed, Rosguill talk 21:28, 13 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Reclose as keep with a proper closing statement. Zxcvbnm is right; WP:SNOW is inapplicable here, and the laconic Article got expanded suggests that the earlier calls for draftification became void as soon as someone improved the page, without examining whether those improvements addressed any of the actual concerns. Had I closed this AfD, I would have done so with a detailed statement highlighting the P&G weakness in many (most?) of the Keeps. A vote (yes, not "!vote") such as, keep - lack of sustained coverage has not been demonstrated shouldn't even be counted. But in the end, an ATD such as Draftify can only be picked when there is consensus against keeping the page as is. It cannot be chosen as an alternative to retention without consensus, and such consensus did not form in this AfD. And with such broad participation, it is highly unlikely that consensus would have shifted meaningfully with a relist.  Had I closed it, I would have likely added a comment allowing for an early renomination, effectively bringing the result closer to a no-consensus. I know some DRV regulars aren't big fans of my early renomination invitation closes, but I find that a fresh AfD after a month or two often gets clearer consensus than an immediate relist, especially for an AfD that has already been befouled with nonsense votes. Owen× ☎ 23:02, 13 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Relist (commenter at AFD). Bad close that appears to be more of a vote count than an evaluation. Sergecross73 msg me 01:54, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Relist. Plainly an inappropriate closure as SNOW keep, and definitely should have been closed by an admin who could explain how they weighted calls for draftification and arguments over SUSTAINED. JoelleJay (talk) 02:52, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse At some point, the voice of editors saying "Yes, we think this does belong in Wikipedia" becomes the ROUGHCONSENSUS, even if they articulate policies inexactly. As DGAF DGFA (When in doubt, don't delete.) makes clear, ties, if we can ever truly have such a thing, go to keeping the content. Jclemens (talk) 05:04, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Relist (commenter at AFD). Zx is right that most of the keep !votes were not based on whether the topic meets our PAGs (mostly whether the article meets WP:SUSTAINED), and considering that there were suggestions to draftify the article, the discussion should have been relisted. Just because >80% of the votes were !keep, it does not mean that the article should be kept. What matters in discussions is whether the topic meets our PAGs and most of the !keep votes did not address that. I should clarify that I was one of the !keep votes, but still, the discussion should not have been closed per WP:SNOW. It should have been relisted. Vacant0 (talk • contribs) 11:56, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Vacate (reclose). The AfD ran long enough, close enough to the full duration, that there is no need to ensure it runs for significantly longer by relisting. The close was clearly not a good application of the snowball clause, and that's something worth fixing. Because reclosing after a non-convincing SNOW is cheap: if the consensus is as obvious as the original closer claimed, the effort is a trivial one, and if the consensus is not as obvious, it's highly justified and worth it that there should be a different outcome, or the same but with an appropriate closing statement (or, potentially, a relist).—Alalch E. 13:44, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Vacate the close as a bad non-admin close as snow, and Relist or Reclose.  The closer is advised that if two of their snow closes are taken to DRV in two days, and the DRV editors have doubts about both of them, maybe they should refrain from snow closes, at least for a few months.  Robert McClenon (talk) 17:39, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse even if it's not a well argued AfD, the idea that this would be relisted is kind of astounding to me, and I also would have closed it as keep. I don't care if an admin wants to undo the close, that's their right, but I really don't see the point of this DRV. SportingFlyer T·C 18:43, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Vacate (reclose as keep) As the article creator, I made multiple rebuttals to ᴢxᴄᴠʙɴᴍ in the AfD discussion disputing his nomination and broad characterization of the keep votes as supposedly unresponsive to his points. This AfD is plainly not fit for WP:SNOW close, but substantive participation has been significant enough on both sides for an admin to reclose as keep, rather than relist. Per OwenX, I have no issue with reminding that articles on neologisms are particularly fit for early renomination. ViridianPenguin🐧 (💬) 21:17, 14 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Reclose as keep While the keep close is correct and the AfD could not have been closed any other way, the SNOW part is not. The AfD should be reclosed by an admin with a better rationale. Jumpytoo Talk 06:30, 15 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
endorse There may be a user issue here that needs addressing.  But snow keep is within discretion even if it isn't the best close (just keep). And reopening to remove the SNOW makes no sense as changing the word doesn't change the outcome in any way AFAIK. Hobit (talk) 01:34, 16 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse, but per User:OwenX. Do not relist or reopen.  Read advice at WP:RENOM. Given the new material and sources since the opening of the AfD, a substantially updated AfD nomination is needed. —SmokeyJoe (talk) 06:58, 16 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse. While the discussion was not the best, it is true there was no significant chance of it going anywhere except towards keep. That's the meaning of WP:SNOW: "snowball chance in hell". In any case to "reclose as keep" without invoking WP:SNOW is correct but it seems quite inane WP:BURO to me.--cyclopiaspeak! 13:56, 20 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
We have a guideline that contentious AfDs should not be closed by non-admins, and there is also a general expectation that closing statements include P&G-based reasoning for such AfDs. Given the number of keep !votes that did not address SUSTAINED, and the several that tried to rebut it with essays that misinterpret P&Gs (the burden, as outlined in multiple places in policy, is solidly on those wishing to retain to demonstrate a topic has sustained coverage or is indisputably LASTING; the claim that we should wait until enough time has passed to demonstrate SUSTAINED is not met is directly negated by two policies), the !vote balance is much closer than appropriate for a non-admin and certainly not eligible for SNOW. JoelleJay (talk) 19:27, 20 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
This misstates the position; it is not that the AfD keep voters presume that all neologisms will have lasting coverage, it is just that for the reasons expressed in WP:NOTTOOSOON, when a neologism has received significant coverage by reliable sources, it is inherently speculative to presume that such coverage will quickly dissipate. Regardless, I agree that citing WP:SNOW was inappropriate and a clearer closing rationale was needed here. ViridianPenguin🐧 (💬) 03:30, 21 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse (WP:BURO) and encourage the closer to refrain from closing discussions before the seven day window has passed. The only acceptable close of the discussion was "keep" but the discussion should have lasted another day.  --Enos733 (talk) 16:33, 21 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Endorse as the sources for this as a keep only seem to continue to improve in time as well. Though they were sufficiently strong even at the close. Iljhgtn (talk) 20:07, 21 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
Do not disturb close.  I was tempted to close the DRV since despite the diversity of bolded phrases I think that there is a pretty clear consensus.  However, doing so (as a non-admin myself) would be in violation of the advice that the close would contain so I'll just give my thoughts here as a comment.  I see rough consensus both that the close as Keep is correct on the merits and that it should not have been made early by a non-admin citing the Snowball Clause.  In such a case I see no need to procedurally reclose the AfD, just note that the DRV finds non-reversible error and possibly leave a note on the closer's Talk page suggesting they wait before making similar closes.  Eluchil404 (talk) 20:47, 21 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
It costs the same amount of effort for an admin to reclose, so it's good to do it to satisfy the doubters and help everyone move on. WP:Reclosing controversial snowcloses as regular closes is cheap. —Alalch E. 21:21, 21 August 2025 (UTC)[reply]
